segments.text: a little bit about you and your history, and what year did you begin reporting and anchoring?
In Houston, essentially, I started in 1961.
I came here.
Dan Rather was at Channel 11 at that time, and I was in Tulsa.
And they brought two people down from the Tulsa station to work down here, and I was one of the people brought down.
He was my boss.
And he became famous, of course, with Carla.
And that was in September.
In May the following year, he left to go to CBS.
And so I worked with him for that period of time and learned a great deal from him about writing.
But there were essentially three news stations in town, KPRC, Channel 2, KHOU, Channel 11, KTRK, Channel 13.
Channel 8 was on the air, but that was it.
And 8 didn't do any news.
So there were three news stations.
And 2 was the dominant station.
until the hurricane came, put Rather on the map, but also put Eleven on the map.
And Eleven stayed number one for, I'd say, about eight or ten years.
Then 13's dominance came into play and remains there now, though we're just about to beat them, and I think we probably will.
If we don't get them now, we'll get them very shortly.
What year did Channel 2 begin operation?
I think 2 is 35 years old, so I think...
I think they were on the air in the 50s, something like that.
But I'm not really sure.
Not very many viewers, not many people had TV.

No, that was a situation where traditionally the NBC station was the first station in the market because NBC radio had a kind of dominance, and RCA was making electronics equipment for television, so they stocked NBC stations first.
And people would go down to the supermarkets
or not supermarket, to the store, like a Foley store, and look in the window.
You'd see them gathered around the front window to watch television.
It was a very unique situation.
Then pretty soon got to where everybody got one of their house, then color came.
First the cable came to bring you live programs, and then color came, and then now VCRs, and the industry keeps changing.
One of the reasons it's been interesting, it's been a very fluid industry.
It always changes.
It may seem to be the same to the guy at home,
But internally, it's changing every day.
You can't keep up with it.
What kind of stories would I see if I were a viewer in 1960?
Same kind of stories you see now, except probably more emphasis on crime, because crime's easier to do.
The reason you see so much crime on television and so much crime on radio, and essentially so much crime in newspapers, is because it's an easy thing to cover.
There's a body.
There's a police car.
There's a light going around that attracts people to it.
There are people around gathering.
Everybody's got an idea as to what happened or what might have happened, whether it was an automobile accident or a shooting or a robbery.
Well, crime may be visual, but is the crime rate increasing?
Crime rate increases, I think, with the general population.
I think that is a fact.
And there probably is more crime now than there was in the 1950s because there are more of us.
And certainly in Houston, there's more crime because we have created a, I don't know what you want to call it, that we've created down there.
When I came to Houston in 1961, there
Now you've got in that same tight area that's uninhabitable.
Anybody who had any sense wouldn't live there in the first place because it's not a fit place to live.
Too hot.
It's too everything.
So now we've got 3 million people in there.
So yes, there's more crime.
Television didn't do that.
Radio didn't do that.
News papers didn't do that.
Do you see crime being committed more violently than in the 60s?
I began as a police reporter, and I saw people shocked, stabbed, choked, and gassed.
And I've seen a couple of people electrocuted in the electric chair.
I don't see, I don't know that you get more violent than that.
I think because of the perception is, because of what television is doing, what mass media is doing, is that there seems to be a much more violent attitude about people now than we always had.
But you have to understand, there's a good side to television.
maybe, and that is in the 1960s, television may have showed us that war is really hell.
I mean, MacArthur said it was, and Harry Truman said it was, but nobody really believed that much because it was really John Wayne, wasn't it?
It was what we saw at the movies on Saturday.
Television brought the living room war to us, and we haven't had a major confrontation of the war since Vietnam.
Maybe we won't have.
I don't know.
But before that, we had World War II and World War I and the Spanish-American War and the Civil War.
And we had inquisitions in Europe, and we had seven crusades.
And man has not figured out a more violent way to be than man was then.
Excellent.
Thank you, Roger.
You're very welcome, Ron.
Yeah, you're quite welcome.
Very historical.
Yes.
When you worked there at KPRC in 1960, were there as many female reporters then as there are now?
No, no, no, no, no, no, no, no.
Jessica Savage came in the 60s, and I can't recall exactly when she came.
Jessica Savage and Bob Nicholas were both hired the same week.
Now, that's a significant thing because Bob Nicholas is black.
And Jessica Savage is a woman.
And the community was pretty much decided that neither one of them had the right to give them the news.
I mean, certainly a woman had no business
giving the news.
And what year was this?
Well, sometime in the 60s.
I don't know exactly when it was.
60s, 70s, maybe 70s.
I don't know.
I lose track of time.
You know, when you get my age, things fly by.
But in that age, it was very controversial.
Oh, yeah.
You know, Jess did the Saturday night news.
Bob did the Sunday night news.
And people said, we're never going to watch your weekends again on Channel 11.
That's where it was at that time.
Because you've got a black man on there.
God knows black people don't have any sense.
You've got a woman on there.
God knows women don't have any sense.
Who hired these?
The management of the television station at that time, the Corinthian Broadcasting Company, made the decision that the time had come to make a gigantic leap into modern times and did this.
I suppose a man named Jim Riddsdale was the man who did it.
The news director was a fellow named Dick John.
It was a very radical first time.
Yes.
We got death threats.
We got threats from sponsors that they were going to quit watching, going to quit doing these things, going to quit sponsoring the programs.
And in the end, of course, it all worked out very well.
Now I think 40% of the newsrooms around the country, newspapers and radio and television stations, are women.
They're being paid the same amount of money that men are being paid.
They're doing the same kind of jobs.
They're probably doing it better.
which is a terrible thing to admit, but the fact is they have a sense of propriety, a sense of understanding how things go together in an orderly way, which makes a good reporter.
A good reporter ought to know how to orderly put things together.
A woman maybe knows that instinctively.
Maybe God gave them that kind of instinct to know how to manage things.
So they're pretty good managers and thus pretty good reporters.
And I want to say they have
And forgive me for using gutter words, but they've got just as many balls as men have, and that's a great shock to those of us who are men.
Is Jan Carson characteristic of those qualities?
Absolutely.
Absolutely.
Yeah, she's tough.
She's attractive.
If you want somebody to be attractive, she's attractive.
She's tough.
If you want somebody to be tough, she can sit down and write a news story as well as I can and better.
Does TV emphasize now the glamour?
Always have.
More than it has in the past.
Television started in the beginning.
People watched television not because they thought they were going to learn any great new things.
They were going to see some things on the newsreel that they had not previously seen, open up the wide vistas that way.
But you had John Cameron Swayze read the Camel News Caravan.
That was the very first thing.
It was just wonderful.
And the guy, I can't think of his name, who did CBS, the first CBS newscast now, he's
Robert Kraut, another handsome guy with a mustache.
People thought that that's the way it was supposed to be, just an attractive guy sitting there reading the news, and that was it.
We got past attractive guys reading the news, but they were still accused of flash and trash.
But it's still there, just like it's still there in newspapers.
I don't suppose the Post or the Chronicle started putting color in their newspapers because they knew that that was going to enhance the value of the news.
They knew that if they put that in there, people might pick it up and look at it.
It's a business.
It's a business.
And television's a business, and don't you ever forget that.
Don't let anybody tell you it isn't, because if they tell you that, it's a lie.
Newspapers are a business.
We don't exist for any other reason than to make somebody money.
Now, because we can make somebody money, we also can do things that we ought to be doing, and we do things for the community.
At our station, at every television station, they do things for the community that the community doesn't even realize.
They run
They run spots for the Leukemia Society free.
It doesn't cost anything to run those public service announcements.
That's part of the thing they said they'd do to get the license.

They put fringe programs on the air maybe in weird times when no one's watching, but they put programs on the air that give people exposure to how the other half lives, which is very valuable and very good.
Newspapers do the same thing.
Radio does the same thing.
So you can gripe all you want to about it being a business, and we're really in there, oh, we care about the ratings.
You bet.
I care about the ratings.
So I got a good enough rating to get to work tomorrow.
It's as simple a thing as that.
The guy here at Foley's worries about the ratings, see?
His rating is a cash register.
If he sells enough in the camera department, he'll get to sell cameras tomorrow.
At Texas A&M, if a teacher teaches well enough and produces good enough results from his classroom, he'll get to teach next year.
It's a struggle to survive.
It's survival of the fittest.
That's what ratings are.
I'm old before my time because I worry about who watched last night.
I worry about those numbers.
I want to know when I get to work today what my numbers were last night.
I really want to know.
Can those numbers be trusted?
Are they reliable?
Let's assume that you wanted to play a game of craps.
You really want to shoot dice somewhere, and there's only one crap game in town.
You're probably going to go and someone will say, well, what if they're loaded?
But I don't know whether they're loaded or not.
If I'm going to play the game, that's the only place to go to play.
The only way you can tell what's happening in television is by a ratings thing that may or may not be loaded.
But it's the only way to check.
Not the best, but the only.
It's the only way anybody's come up with.
It'd be really wonderful if they could see if you put a little thing on front of your television set and you turn it on and it says, well, somebody was watching Channel 2 last night.
No, it doesn't.
It says the television set was on Channel 2 last night.
It doesn't say whether they watched.
It doesn't say whether they listened.
It doesn't say whether they learned anything.
We don't know how to measure that.
Okay.
Do you think that TV news directors overemphasize the graphics and the glamour and the live shots?
Yeah, they're interested in that sort of thing because it all goes together in a kind of package just like the editor of a newspaper probably overemphasizes the graphics.
At the expense of truth in journalism?
No, those things don't have anything to do with each other.
If you believe that, then that's to say that you couldn't have an attractive picture of the Pope behind you as you're talking about the Pope.
and that you somehow would be cheapening the pulp or cheapening the story.
That doesn't make a difference.
Graphics are used in every form of business, in every form of teaching.
There's always been somebody who had a graph.
There's always somebody who had a picture to explain how something worked.
If television does the same thing, what's wrong with that?
It's a teaching tool.
I can say, I did a story the other night about the wind shear that the airplane ran into at Dallas.
Well, I know what wind shear was.
I mean, I've heard the word.
Most of my viewers have heard the word, but they don't know what it is.
So the artist people did a thing of a down, you know, an arrow.
They did a cloud with an airplane in it and an arrow coming down at it like a gust of wind.
Now, that's flash, okay?
But it also helps somebody say, oh, that's what a wind shear is, a sudden wind that comes down and hits the front of the airplane and makes it crash.
Now,
The question is, could we tell the story without it?
And the answer is yes.
The question is, could we tell it as effectively?
And the answer is, maybe not.
Well, does it cheapen the story and bring it down to an elementary level?
You've got to understand that the average person that we're talking to is not a college graduate.
Is that insulting to the average viewer?
No, I don't think so.
It's not insulting to me if someone, if I pick up something and I say, well, I understand that.
It doesn't insult me.
If I pick up a newspaper, and I go back to newspapers because I read newspapers all the time, lots of newspapers, and I enjoy them.
USA Today doesn't insult me because it has a graph telling how many people chew gum on Thursday.
I just think, who cares?
But somebody does, you see.
If the story next to it is a good story about how the deficit is affecting the balance of trade, then that doesn't bother me at all.
And if they have a little graph that shows a ship docking and
guys carrying stuff off the ship and putting things back on there as they have done to explain what the balance of trade is.
It doesn't insult my intelligence, and it may help somebody to understand what this thing's all about.
Okay.
Let's draw some differences between newspaper and TV.
Okay.
Does TV suffer from its inadequacy to reach deep down, bring the details out?
Yeah.
We have a time problem.
We have time constraints that we simply cannot get around.
I bet.
30 minutes of news.
You have a 30-minute segment.
How many minutes of news do you have?
12 to 13 minutes of news in it.
That's not counting weather and sports and commercials.
That's very small.
Oh, yeah.
It's not very much time at all.
So you become an editor, and you say, I'm going to tell them about this and such.
You get to play God.
That's one of the worst things about the whole thing, is the producer, anchor, gets to play God a little bit.
And you go home every night wondering if you were the right kind of God today.
All right.
Houston, the market you work in, the 10th-rated market, is the competition stiff?
Yeah, very much so.
Yeah, I think so.
There's a lot of money involved in it.
See, we make a lot of money in the television business.
And when you've got a lot of money involved, you have terrible competition for that dollar so that you can't afford to let down because somebody's after you every time you get a rating point.
If we beat 13, you see, we charge more money for what we sell a spot for in that newspaper.
We sell eight spots in it now, see.
What are some of the magic tricks that producers use to boost the ratings?
Well, they try to put special reports in during rating periods, you know, blockbuster reports on what happened, you know, this story, that story, whatever it might be.
They try to infuse as many of those in as they possibly can.
get promotable things in a newscast, promotable features in a newscast.
Dan Carson is now working on a cosmetic surgery piece, which is fluff.
But you know if you advertise the fact that tonight we're going to show you a breast implant, you might get somebody to watch your newscast.
Chances are you're going to get somebody to watch your newscast.
13, I mean 11, two years ago during those glory days of Amanda Arnold,
did a whole month-long series on sexual attitudes in Houston.
We knew everybody's sexual attitude.
I couldn't care less.
But I had a lot of people say, what do you think about the way 50-year-old women think about sex?
And I'd say, what?
You watch for that?
And they'd say, well, sure.
I wanted to know.
And I'm thinking, oh, it'd be a shoe sale.
Well, that gets back to the viewers.
and their response to the news.
Why do you think some viewers think TV news blows stories out of proportion?
Because in the first place, it's very personal.
It comes into their house, and they see it.
If they see the story on, let's assume there was, let's shoot somebody at a school, OK?
2, 11, 13 are going to shoot somebody, they're going to have a film on that at 5 o'clock, 6 o'clock, 10 o'clock.
Okay?
The numbers.
So, you know, they have, maybe they've blown it out of proportion.
Maybe it shouldn't have been that big a story in the first place.
But it's the story.
In Philadelphia last night at a shopping mall, a woman dressed in army fatigues walks in with a gun and starts shooting.
She shoots 13 or 14 people and kills two of them.
That's going to be on every television station in Philadelphia.
and in every newspaper in Philadelphia for a couple of days, and it's going to be an overkill kind of a situation.
So there you go.
I've got to go do my work here.
Oh, okay.
Okay.
Can I come back in a second?
I think that wraps it up.
Yeah, that's fine.
Great.
Thank you very much.
